document.title: Science Content Standards for California Public Schools Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve

D523F1395DBD4AD0B1A02456645CE425.description:
Identify changes in natural phenomena over time without manipulating the
phenomena (e.g., a tree limb, a grove of trees, a stream, a hillslope).

B9B93EA44FE3404D810D8D27C0F460F5.description:
Interpret events by sequence and time from natural phenomena (e.g., the relative
ages of rocks and intrusions).

7296476E92FD408EA975F3F4A2664BFC.description:
Read a topographic map and a geologic map for evidence provided on the maps
and construct and interpret a simple scale map.

FAB80D653D624060821233847B446162.description: Recognize whether evidence is consistent with a proposed explanation.

3EEFA561340E4D8389D5E62B21F7C1D5.description:
Communicate the steps and results from an investigation in written reports and
oral presentations.

3095AE502EA24D3085FE6723C053C2B5.description:
Construct appropriate graphs from data and develop qualitative statements
about the relationships between variables.

F8ABE52F116249CB9ED4DAA83531CEF6.description:
Select and use appropriate tools and technology (including calculators, computers,
balances, spring scales, microscopes, and binoculars) to perform tests, collect
data, and display data.

CED83A37F4744DCFA9A921F3E6E8460D.description:
Investigation and Experimentation: Scientific progress is made by asking meaningful questions and conducting careful
investigations. As a basis for understanding this concept and addressing the content
in the other three strands, students should develop their own questions and perform
investigations. Students will:

E626220DD563437682A9C6945A1CB39E.description: Students know the natural origin of the materials used to make common objects.

6FB31AA12F524EF194870DD393B01CAF.description:
Students know different natural energy and material resources, including air, soil,
rocks, minerals, petroleum, fresh water, wildlife, and forests, and know how to
classify them as renewable or nonrenewable.

3932658ED5574303AC4A737E9DDDB1D6.description:
Students know the utility of energy sources is determined by factors that are
involved in converting these sources to useful forms and the consequences of the
conversion process.

C910DA8A941E4FEDA215FECC4231AF11.description:
Resources:  Sources of energy and materials differ in amounts, distribution, usefulness, and the
time required for their formation. As a basis for understanding this concept:

43D2D8E1975245E992A4294B46FFE579.description:
Students know the number and types of organisms an ecosystem can support
depends on the resources available and on abiotic factors, such as quantities of
light and water, a range of temperatures, and soil composition.

BD79294219624517B389D23743FB6CFC.description:
Students know different kinds of organisms may play similar ecological roles in
similar biomes.

7CBF4377EAD14F1C8467D6121C02B1B3.description:
Students know populations of organisms can be categorized by the functions they
serve in an ecosystem.

F3CDDE650DB948D7B17C451A59E43450.description:
Students know matter is transferred over time from one organism to others in the
food web and between organisms and the physical environment.

FAAD800E7E3949E8B0CD81C6877A6F56.description:
Students know energy entering ecosystems as sunlight is transferred by producers
into chemical energy through photosynthesis and then from organism to organism
through food webs.

D48278934BF74D86836AB7A11EC87C2B.description:
Ecology: Organisms in ecosystems exchange energy and nutrients among themselves and
with the environment. As a basis for understanding this concept:

1C44F9F4A6C04575A1E86047FD54DED7.description:
Students know differences in pressure, heat, air movement, and humidity result in
changes of weather.

DF9B57AA85814D85AC2BE9744E2D71E4.description: Students know convection currents distribute heat in the atmosphere and oceans.

16F134A859E24698B5EED13A2138F667.description:
Students know heat from Earth’s interior reaches the surface primarily through
convection.

F9E6C4043D7642A6A5D26BCC234A1629.description:
Students know solar energy reaches Earth through radiation, mostly in the form of
visible light.

1205FA61241C4465869C23DEA28735E7.description:
Students know the sun is the major source of energy for phenomena on Earth’s
surface; it powers winds, ocean currents, and the water cycle.

EF382AA981F6427680477225D3615446.description:
Energy in the Earth's System: Many phenomena on Earth’s surface are affected by the transfer of energy through
radiation and convection currents. As a basis for understanding this concept:

845F8ACB0B89483F816C6E0E08A77A27.description:
Students know heat energy is also transferred between objects by radiation (radiation
can travel through space).

5EADD07B86FC467AA7CC45C1028CCD87.description:
Students know heat flows in solids by conduction (which involves no flow of
matter) and in fluids by conduction and by convection (which involves flow of
matter).

83C75FDF3BEF4E9486288BDADCAA7B2D.description:
Students know that when fuel is consumed, most of the energy released becomes
heat energy.

DCCC04E7251840AC96A65650403FFA83.description:
Students know energy can be carried from one place to another by heat flow or by
waves, including water, light and sound waves, or by moving objects.

5DB70EE20E7E4228B141CE2EBC939656.description:
Heat (Thermal Energy- Physical Sciences):  Heat moves in a predictable flow from warmer objects to cooler objects until all the
objects are at the same temperature. As a basis for understanding this concept:

E6A1AF9343C642F1BED572703309825B.description:
Students know earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, landslides, and floods change
human and wildlife habitats.

51CF892E55824679A51293C3E3CAC797.description:
Students know beaches are dynamic systems in which the sand is supplied by
rivers and moved along the coast by the action of waves.

1016EC88FD104FAF9FDA428CEBC25380.description:
Students know rivers and streams are dynamic systems that erode, transport
sediment, change course, and flood their banks in natural and recurring patterns.

1DDC3D7B96CE48E2AC7C7D0F1EFDF1B2.description:
Students know water running downhill is the dominant process in shaping the
landscape, including California’s landscape.

F03192A42B65414A870033A83A42E895.description:
Shaping the Earth's Surface: Topography is reshaped by the weathering of rock and soil and by the transportation
and deposition of sediment. As a basis for understanding this concept:

743E32E011C1454381AB1DD22EED3101.description:
Students know how to determine the epicenter of an earthquake and know that
the effects of an earthquake on any region vary, depending on the size of the
earthquake, the distance of the region from the epicenter, the local geology, and
the type of construction in the region.

C77C617FA30043058E400599E1AAD24D.description:
Students know how to explain major features of California geology (including
mountains, faults, volcanoes) in terms of plate tectonics.

B1F77579C5BB40C2AC570FC6D5981308.description:
Students know major geologic events, such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions,
and mountain building, result from plate motions.

11118C22F33C4EC0A6E2D999685D165D.description:
Students know that earthquakes are sudden motions along breaks in the crust
called faults and that volcanoes and fissures are locations where magma reaches
the surface.

8034AA771681421BB3CB372A106E44CF.description:
Students know lithospheric plates the size of continents and oceans move at rates
of centimeters per year in response to movements in the mantle.

4B131B700466487C90B7AB7F1B7F9C45.description:
Students know Earth is composed of several layers: a cold, brittle lithosphere; a
hot, convecting mantle; and a dense, metallic core.

49A913D6D634403DAB5058C7E9160A47.description:
Plate Tectonics and Earth Structure: Plate tectonics accounts for important features of Earth’s surface and major geologic
events. As a basis for understanding this concept:
